APO and the Graduate Club are
conducting a Christmas clothing

Art Lecture
The Evergreen House Foundation will present a lecture,"Rome
and the Roots of the Renaissance," by Professor John E. C. T.
White at 8:30 p.m., December 16,
at Evergreen.
Dr. White, the new chairman of
the department of the history of
art at Hopkins, previously taught
at the University of Manchester
where he was Professor of Art
History and Director of the Whitworth Gallery.
The Evergreen House events,
which are given each year as a
complement to the Humanities
Seminars, are concerned this year
with late classical antiquity.
Dr. White's recent book, Art
and Architecture in Italy, 12501400, appears in the Pelican History of Art Series.
At a reception following the
lecture, the Baltimore Brass
Choir will play selections from
Renaissance music.

Only the ugliest and most distasteful brand of racial
prejudice could be responsible for transforming Hopkins
fraternities (many of whom continue to harbor a policy
of racial and religious discrimination—either tacit or
actual) into potential champions of Civil Liberty.
Yet the possibility of this incredible irony occurred
at a meeting of the I.F.C. last Tuesday evening when
Mr. 11 il ton Schlenger, president of the University Heights
Improvement Association, invited for the purpose of bettering relationships between neighborhood and fraternity, told the organization that the U.H.I.A. was dedicated
to barring negroes from the area. Later, when contacted
by the News-Letter, Schlenger further declared that he
would do his best to prevent negroes from joining or
visiting the chapter houses.
By his crude presentation Schlenger neatly sacrificed any respect he and his organization may have
formally deserved. This, when coupled with the open
support the University Heights Improvement Association
has dedicated to discriminatory practices, justifies disregarding them altogether.
We certainly urge all fraternities concerned to endeavor to keep their houses in a respectable but slightly
run down state, for anything more elaborate would not
be in keeping with the character of the neighborhood.
Yet to heed any of Schlengers warnings would be a crude
parody of the principles upon which our University
stands.
Yet those members of the I.F.C. whose indignation
would take them into open battle with the prejudice of
Mr. Schlenger would do well to remember that within
their own organization are representatives of fraternities that in clause and practice adhere to his sentiments.
We recommend that the I.F.C. set aside its collective mops in favor of a house cleaning of a more basic
nature.

Only the ugliest and most distasteful brand of racial
prejudice could be responsible for transforming Hopkins
fraternities (many of whom continue to harbor a policy
of racial and religious discrimination—either tacit or
actual) into potential champions of Civil Liberty.
Yet the possibility of this incredible irony occurred
at a meeting of the I.F.C. last Tuesday evening when
Mr. 11 il ton Schlenger, president of the University Heights
Improvement Association, invited for the purpose of bettering relationships between neighborhood and fraternity, told the organization that the U.H.I.A. was dedicated
to barring negroes from the area. Later, when contacted
by the News-Letter, Schlenger further declared that he
would do his best to prevent negroes from joining or
visiting the chapter houses.
By his crude presentation Schlenger neatly sacrificed any respect he and his organization may have
formally deserved. This, when coupled with the open
support the University Heights Improvement Association
has dedicated to discriminatory practices, justifies disregarding them altogether.
We certainly urge all fraternities concerned to endeavor to keep their houses in a respectable but slightly
run down state, for anything more elaborate would not
be in keeping with the character of the neighborhood.
Yet to heed any of Schlengers warnings would be a crude
parody of the principles upon which our University
stands.
Yet those members of the I.F.C. whose indignation
would take them into open battle with the prejudice of
Mr. Schlenger would do well to remember that within
their own organization are representatives of fraternities that in clause and practice adhere to his sentiments.
We recommend that the I.F.C. set aside its collective mops in favor of a house cleaning of a more basic
